involvement_in_cases.name: The alleged ‘flash crash’ trader used anonymously-owned companies
involvement_in_cases.story:
On Tuesday a former futures trader was arrested in a suburban semi-detached house in London. Navinder Singh Sarao has been accused by the U.S. authorities of being in part responsible for the 2010 “flash crash” where the U.S. Dow Jones index plunged 600 points in less than five minutes.

Tuesday’s arrest, and the accompanying criminal charges, lay bare the vulnerability of the world’s financial markets. It also shows the role of opaque shell companies.

The criminal complaint filed by the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) alleges that Saroa used anonymously-owned companies in tax havens of Nevis and Anguilla to protect his assets. According to the DoJ, Sarao incorporated Nav Sarao Milking Markets Limited in the Caribbean tax haven of Nevis, and International Guarantee Corporation in the UK haven of Anguilla. The U.S. authorities claim that this was “part of a tax avoidance strategy”.

Neither Anguilla nor Nevis publish any information on who owns or controls companies. This can make it extremely difficult to track down who really lies behind such structures.

Global Witness is campaigning for an end to anonymous company ownership. This case appears to provide yet more evidence for why transparency is so important.

Sarao is currently fighting extradition to the U.S.

involvement_in_cases.name: Scam involving millions of dollars of federal contracts and a string of anonymous companies
involvement_in_cases.story:
Larayne Whitehead and Christopher Johnson defrauded companies out of millions of dollars using a string of anonymously owned American companies. The scam ran from 2007 to 2013 and worked as follows: the conspirators won U.S. government contracts for items ranging from books to snowmobiles by submitting extremely low bids. They then convinced other businesses to act as subcontractors to supply the goods or services, with the promise that the businesses would be paid after the government had paid them.[i] The subcontractors were never paid and the scammers took all of the fees for themselves. Whitehead and Johnson continued to set up new companies, often under false names, making it difficult for both the businesses and federal authorities to track them down.[ii]

An FBI investigation which finally uncovered the scam, revealed that the conspirators had set up at least 14 shell companies across America.[iii] Some of these companies were anonymous, set up using false names and with UPS stores listed as their addresses. If the U.S. government were to require companies bidding for government contracts to have to reveal their ultimate beneficial owners, it would be more difficult for people like Whitehead and Johnson to get away with crimes like this. 

Whitehead and Johnson were both sentenced to 18 months in federal prison and ordered to pay millions of dollars in restitutions.[iv]

involvement_in_cases.name: Angolan officials used anonymous companies to get lucrative oil deals
involvement_in_cases.story:
In 2010, Global Witness raised concerns over the secrecy surrounding an Angolan oil deal[1]. It later turned out that three senior Angolan officials had undisclosed interests in anonymously owned companies that had been awarded valuable stakes in the impoverished country’s oil sector. [2]

The Angolan state oil company, Sonangol, awarded the US company Cobalt exploration licences in two Angolan oil blocks in 2010. Colbalt was assigned by the Angolan government two local partners with no track record in the oil industry and with hidden ownership: Nazaki Oil and Gáz S.A and Alper Oil Limitada[3]. The two companies potentially stood to make millions of dollars from the deal[4].

However, in 2012 the Financial Times revealed that Nazaki’s beneficial owners in fact included three powerful Angolan officials: Manuel Vicente, who was head of Sonangol at the time of allocation and is now the Angolan vice-president; General Manuel Helder Vieira Dias “Kopelipa”, the head of the presidency’s military bureau; and General Leopoldino Fragoso do Nascimento, a former head of communications in the presidency[5]. Vicente and Kopelipa held their shares in Nazaki via another anonymous company, Grupo Aquattro Internacional, which was named as a shareholder in Nazaki[6].

Vicente and Kopelipa admitted to holding a concealed interest in the oil deal[7]. Nascimento has made no comment.Vicente, as head of the Angolan state oil company, had a pivotal role in deciding which companies would be granted rights to this oil block.[8] In spite of an extremely valuable contract being awarded to the company in which they secretly held shares, Vicente and Kopelipa deny any wrongdoing in the awarding of oil concessions[9].

Due to its associations with Nazaki, Cobalt has been under investigation for potential violations of the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practice Act by the SEC and Department of Justice though the SEC dropped the case in 2015. Cobalt denies any misconduct or knowledge of the secret involvement of Angolan officials in the oil deal[10]. The ongoing investigation demonstrates the risks of doing business with anonymous companies.

involvement_in_cases.name: A defence contractor conned the US military into paying inflated prices for food and water for troops
involvement_in_cases.story:
In 2014, two members of the international logistics group Supreme pleaded guilty to deliberately overcharging the US military for food and drink.[1] Supreme had a contract to supply food and water to US troops in Afghanistan.[2] Emails sent between Supreme executives revealed in court documents show that between 2005 and 2009, they deliberately inflated prices, with marks up of up to 60%.[3] The scam cost the U.S. government $48 million.[4]

Central to the fraud was the anonymously owned company Jamal Ahli Foods Co (JAFCO), based in the UAE.[5] To hide its relationship to Supreme, JAFCO was held in the names of a Dubai sponsor.[6] Fake letterheads were created and members of staff were hired in the name of JAFCO to make the company look real.[7] JAFCO was in fact secretly controlled by Supreme, who used the company as a middle man to mark up prices.[8]

The scam came to light when a former executive of Supreme blew the whistle and alerted the U.S. government.[9] Supreme was ordered to pay $288 million in the criminal case. Supreme agreed to pay a further $146 million in a related civil case, which also included the company allegedly false billing the Department of Defense for fuel and transporting American troops to Afghanistan.[10]

involvement_in_cases.name: American engineering company KBR bribed Nigerian officials to win lucrative gas deal
involvement_in_cases.story:
In 2009, Texas-based Kellogg Brown & Root (KBR) pleaded guilty to bribing Nigerian officials to win contracts to build a liquefied natural gas plant on Bonny Island inNigeria.[1]

In what is known as the ‘Halliburton Bribery Scandal’[2], after KBR’s parent company Halliburton, $132 million in ‘consulting fees’ was paid to the anonymously ownedGibraltar company Tri-Star Investments. The money was really intended to be used, in part, for bribes for high ranking Nigerian officials.[3]

Documents revealed by Swiss Leaks show that bribes were transferred via HSBC Geneva. Switzerland’s infamous bank secrecy laws made it perfect for moving bribe money,with one of the fraudsters holding five separate accounts at HSBC Private Bank (Suisse).[4]

As part of the plea agreement, KBR agreed to pay a $402 million criminal fine.[5] KBR and Halliburton jointly agreed to pay $177 million to settle a civil suit whichaccused the two companies of breaking bribery laws.[6] The former CEO of KBR, Albert "Jack" Stanley was sentenced to 30 months in prison in 2012 after acknowledgingthat his judgement had been clouded by “ego, ambition and alcohol".[7]

involvement_in_cases.story:
In 2009, the UN Security Council imposed an arms embargo on Eritrea due to the country’s support for armed groups in neighbouring Somalia.[1]

In 2012, the UN Security Council group responsible for monitoring the arms embargo reported evidence that a UK company, Espace Soft Trading Ltd, could potentially have been supplying parts and services to the Eritrean air force.[2] Business News Europe has also repeated this allegation.[3]

Espace Soft Trading is owned by nominee shareholders, meaning that the real owners are hidden.[4]

Global Witness is not aware of any attempts by the authorities to investigate Espace Soft Trading. We wrote to Espace Soft Trading to give them an opportunity to comment on these allegations but they did not reply.

involvement_in_cases.name: The dead company owner and the Central Asia money laundering scandal
involvement_in_cases.story:
There are few better examples of how extensive the problem of anonymous company ownership is than the case of the dead Russian who owned a company used as a front for what appears to be a billion dollar money-laundering operation.  

Global Witness showed how billions of dollars of suspicious transactions passed through Kyrgyz bank accounts owned by companies registered in UK, New Zealand and Bulgaria.  The money flowed out of the accounts just before a revolution in Kyrgyzstan.  Three of the UK companies had US $1.2 billion running through their accounts despite not being involved in any real business that Global Witness could ascertain.  One of these companies told the UK company registry it was dormant despite having $1.1 million flowing through its accounts. 

The names of the people behind the companies were hidden in various ways.  Some companies had nominee directors, others were owned by companies registered in places such as the British Virgin Islands.  In one case, the identity of a dead man from Russia was used as the front for a UK company.  This person had died three years before the company was set up, yet was listed as the company’s owner and he even ‘attended’ a company meeting in London, according to filings made to the UK company registry.[1] 

[1] Global Witness, Grave Secrecy, http://www.globalwitness.org/library/grave-secrecy

involvement_in_cases.name: Russian crime boss conned investors out of millions
involvement_in_cases.story:
The FBI has described Semion Mogilevich as “the most dangerous mobster in the world,” allegedly “involved in weapons trafficking, contract murders, extortion, drug trafficking, and prostitution on an international scale.”[1]

According to an indictment, that reputation did not stop the Russian from setting up a vast network of anonymous companies, stretching from Eastern Pennsylvania to the United Kingdom,[2] which allowed him to cheat the stock market and steal over $150 million from investors in the United States and overseas.[3] Many of the investors lost their pensions and retirement savings.[4]

Using his web of anonymous companies, Mogilevich is said to have created the illusion of a successful international business,[5] supposedly trading in industrial magnets. This was complete with glossy annual reports and stock market listings.[6]

The reality was very different. By inflating the price of his companies through manipulating securities and false reporting, including reportedly lying to the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mogilevich convinced investors to purchase millions in stocks in a company that allegedly did no real business. Those involved lost millions.

In spite of several arrest warrants issued against him, Mogilevich still lives freely in Moscow, according to the FBI. He has not been convicted for these crimes.

The case shows how the secrecy that anonymous owners rely on breeds market instability and erodes investor confidence.

involvement_in_cases.name: Aspiring American entrepreneurs swindled out of their capital by fraudsters
involvement_in_cases.story:
Each of them had a dream. Whether it was opening a winery in Arkansas or renovating a golf course in Colorado, they were regular people who needed investment to make that dream a reality.[1]

Fresh out of prison for fraud, Wesley Wayne Austin and his accomplices set up ghost companies in South Dakota to swindle these aspiring American entrepreneurs out of their capital.[2]

Offering short-term investments in an imaginary biofuel project, or large loans in return for six-figure application fees, they tricked investors into wiring money up front, then used it to fund lavish lifestyles or pay off earlier investors in their Ponzi scam.[3]

In total they promised over $1.4 billion in loans and sought over $10.6 million in fees and supposed investments, swindling their victims out of at least $3.3 million.[4] Austin was sentenced to 11 years in prison in 2011.

involvement_in_cases.name: Los Zetas drug trafficking in racehorse scandal
involvement_in_cases.story:
In the past decade, the international drug trade through Mexico has ripped apart the fabric of its society, causing many thousands of deaths and flooding American streets with drugs and dirty money. The governments of both countries have carried out crackdowns on both sides of the border, but the trade is flourishing today and the blood continues to flow. Meanwhile, the drug kingpins look for new ways to move and hide their cash. 

The biggest of Mexico’s drug gangs is the Los Zetas cartel, whose former leader Miguel Ángel Treviño was notorious for dismember­ing his victims while still alive.

From 2008, the Zetas used anonymous companies, including from Oklahoma, in a scheme to launder millions of dollars of drug money into the United States, with the true ownership hidden behind frontmen.[1] The money was hidden behind the purchase of race horses, some of whom were given names such as ‘Number One Cartel’ and ‘Morning Cartel’. The horses were incredibly successful and reported to win the cartel several million dollars.

Fourteen people, including Treviño, were indicted on money laundering charges by the U.S. in 2012.[2] Treviño was captured in Mexico in July 2013.[3] As of September 2013, four co-defendants from the original indictment have yet to be caught. Nine people have been sentenced for their role in the scheme.[4]

[2] FBI, Federal grand jury indicts Los Zetas leader in money laundering scheme, http://www.fbi.gov/sanantonio/press-releases/2012/federal-grand-jury-in-texas-indicts-los-zetas-leader-in-money-laundering-scheme

involvement_in_cases.name: Elderly tricked out of their life savings
involvement_in_cases.story:
Roger Lee Shoss and Nicolette Loisel knew the power a fake company could give them over vulnerable people. The two lawyers from Texas stole the identities of dormant, publicly-traded, companies from Delaware[1] and Nevada[2] and set up sham companies with the same names.

This trick allowed them to target elderly victims with telemarketing schemes, and persuade them to buy shares in the worthless enterprises by sending money to bank accounts controlled by Robert Paul Gunter in central Florida.

The scam fooled thousands of elderly citizens from around the world into investing more than $127 million.[3] The co-conspirators spent the victims’ money on properties across the globe, an airplane, boats, vehicles and more.[4]

In 2013, Gunter was sentenced to 25 years in jail. Shoss was sentenced to 10 months in pris­on and Loisel was sentenced to 12 months.[5]

involvement_in_cases.name: The President’s son and the stolen resource wealth of Equatorial Guinea
involvement_in_cases.story:
Equatorial Guinea is massively rich in natural resources but its people are some of the poorest in the world. Where’s all the money gone? It appears, in part, to have gone into the pockets of the president’s son, via a string of anonymous companies.

The U.S. Department of Justice says that Teodorin Obiang spent more than $300 million in stolen money on luxury goods, sports cars and houses.[1] The assets included a $30 mil­lion mansion in Malibu, California and a $38 million private jet. Anonymous companies incorporated in California were used to open bank accounts in the U.S. and buy a California mansion while keeping the real owner of the money secret, while a company incorporated in the British Virgin Islands was used to buy the plane.[2]

The president’s son is facing court cases in France and the U.S. He is currently in settlement talks with the U.S. over two asset forfeiture cases that seek to seize the mansion and private jet. There’s an arrest warrant out for him in France and some of his assets have been seized. But if he was such an obvious corruption risk, why was he allowed to set up these American companies in the first place?

[1] US Department of Justice, Department of Justice seeks to recover more than $70.8 Million in proceeds of corruption from government minister of Equatorial Guinea, 25 October 2011,

[2] United States District Court for the Central District of California, USA vs one white crystal-studded ‘Bad Tour’ glove and other Michael Jackson memorabilia; real property located on Sweetwater Mesa Road in Malabu, California; one 2011 Ferrari 599 GTO, page 49, available from http://www.globalwitness.org/sites/default/files/library/Second%20Amended%20Complaint%206.11.12.pdf

Viktor Bout – on whom the Hollywood film Lord of War is based – is said to have been the world’s largest arms trafficker.[1] His deals fuelled conflicts throughout Africa and elsewhere, even providing weapons to both sides of the same conflict on some occasions. involvement_in_cases.name: NASA and other government contracts stolen from disadvantaged small businesses
involvement_in_cases.story:
In order to give small, disadvantaged businesses a chance, the U.S. government often makes specific contracts available to them. These laudable schemes are potentially open to abuse by con artists – especially when they are able to hide their real identities behind anonymous companies.

Keith Hedman was one such anonymous owner. Hedman set up an anonymous company in Virginia and pretended that an employee, Dawn Hamilton, had founded it so that he could use her Portuguese heritage and history of social disadvantage to win preferen­tial treatment.

Having successfully deceived the Small Business Administration, Hedman was able to fraudulently secure federal government contracts worth $31 million from NASA and other agencies through various means, including by bribing a U.S. government official. Many of these contracts were for private security work for the government.

Hedman then illegally passed the majority of the work to a larger company.[1] The scam generated almost $7 million in salary and payments for the conspirators that they should not have received.[2]

Hedman pleaded guilty, was sentenced to six years in jail and had to return $6 million to the government.[3]

involvement_in_cases.name: Millions stolen from Ohio school children
involvement_in_cases.story:
Education is fundamental to all Americans getting a fair chance in life. One government official denied Ohio school children their dues by setting up a web of fake companies which he then paid millions of dollars for non-existent services.[1] 

Joseph Palazzo was responsible for managing his school district’s IT Department. Between 2007 and 2011, he and his associates set up a number of shell companies that enabled them to steal at least $3.4 million,[2] by submitting fake invoices for IT products and services they never delivered.

According to court documents, the companies were simply shells established to “conceal the illegal nature of such funds and to avoid detection by law enforcement.”[3] Palazzo then authorized the District to pay the invoices by issuing checks to the shell companies. The nominee owners of the shells kept approximately half of the money and gave the other half to Palazzo for his personal enrichment.[4]

Palazzo pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit mail fraud, conspiracy to commit money laundering, and wire fraud, and was sentenced to more than 11 years in prison in 2013.[5]

involvement_in_cases.name: Over $20 million stolen from American taxpayers and Afghan commando troops
involvement_in_cases.story:
The U.S. has spent billions to help Afghanistan turn the page on a past blighted by cor­ruption and conflict. A key part of this effort focuses on equipping and training Afghan commando troops to serve their own people without outside support.

Such efforts are greatly undermined by fraudulent bids by people with inside knowl­edge, like those carried out by Lieutenant Colonel David Young, Michael Taylor and Christopher Harris.[1] Hiding behind anonymous companies, Young illegally passed on information about projects to Taylor, president of the American International Security Corporation (AISC), and Harris, a contractor in Afghanistan. 

This information enabled AISC to design the perfect bid for the project. Between 2007 and 2011, it was awarded approximately $54 million worth of Army contracts, inflat­ing the prices once it had eliminated the competition.[2]

Young, Taylor and Harris stole more than $20 million,[3] covertly transferring funds through U.S. shell companies with nominee directors.[4] They spent the money on houses, an airplane, expensive cars and South African Gold Krugerrand coins.[5] All three have pled guilty.[6]

involvement_in_cases.name: Diversity laws exploited in company ownership to sell fake military parts to the Pentagon
involvement_in_cases.story:
The U.S. Department of Defense must know who it is doing business with, and that the military parts it buys are sound. Yet in recent years, the Pentagon has repeatedly suffered from counterfeit parts infiltrating its supply chain, putting American troops and interests at risk.[1]

One such scam was carried out by Atilla C. Kan, a procurement and operations manager for New York Machinery, a Pentagon supplier. Under the alias John Ryan, Kan formed two shell companies in Wyoming, and pretended they were largely owned by ethnic minorities in order to win preferential treatment for government contracts. They were just two of more than 2,000 companies registered to a small house in Wyoming. Nine of these companies were awarded contracts worth more than $1.6 million, mostly by the Department of Defence.

Both Kan’s companies supplied parts for military tractor-trailers described by the Pentagon as “essential to operating personnel”. Instead of supplying bona-fide parts, Kan reverse-engineered fakes in Turkey that looked just like those made by the approved manufacturer.

The shell companies were later banned from selling parts to the Pentagon for three years, but it is not clear whether the Pentagon now vets its suppliers to see if their real owner can be identified. The risk to U.S. citizens and troops is clear.

Kan pleaded guilty in 2007 to fraud for his role in the scheme to sell substandard parts to the Department of Defense.[2] In 2010, New York Machinery also pleaded guilty to fraud.[3]

[1] Reuters, How two shell companies duped the Pentagon, http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/28/us-usa-shell-companies-pentagon-idUSTRE75R21G20110628 

[2] US Attorney District Of New Jersey, Plea Agreement, page 1, https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/1216298-kan-guilty-%20plea.html#document/p1/a174207

[3] US Attorney District of New Jersey, press release, http://www.justice.gov/usao/nj/Press/files/pdffiles/2010/New%20York%20Machinery%20Plea%20PR.pdf

involvement_in_cases.name: Americans sold fake health insurance plans
involvement_in_cases.story:
Imagine if you bit the bullet and bought a healthcare plan, only to have a legitimate claim rejected by a fake company when you needed it?

That’s what happened to the 17,000 Americans who were the victims of an alleged $28 million health insurance scam made possible by anonymous companies incorporated in Delaware, Mississippi, New Hampshire and South Carolina.

Bart S. Posey, Richard H. Bachman and others are alleged to have sold the fake health care plans and then turned down claims submitted by their victims.[1] Between 2008 and 2010 they are alleged to have used the web of American companies to sell the plans to individuals and employer groups in various states, and to launder their gains and blow the premiums. In total, they are accused of lining their own pockets with $5.4 million[2] that they spent on property, a motorcycle and other luxury goods.[3]

Posey, Bachman and others accused deny the charges. The case is ongoing and the trial is scheduled for January 2015.[4]

involvement_in_cases.name: Americans sold fake health insurance plans
involvement_in_cases.story:
Imagine if you bit the bullet and bought a healthcare plan, only to have a legitimate claim rejected by a fake company when you needed it?

That’s what happened to the 17,000 Americans who were the victims of an alleged $28 million health insurance scam made possible by anonymous companies incorporated in Delaware, Mississippi, New Hampshire and South Carolina.

Bart S. Posey, Richard H. Bachman and others are alleged to have sold the fake health care plans and then turned down claims submitted by their victims.[1] Between 2008 and 2010 they are alleged to have used the web of American companies to sell the plans to individuals and employer groups in various states, and to launder their gains and blow the premiums. In total, they are accused of lining their own pockets with $5.4 million[2] that they spent on property, a motorcycle and other luxury goods.[3]

Posey, Bachman and others accused deny the charges. The case is ongoing and the trial is scheduled for January 2015.[4]

involvement_in_cases.name: Secretive sale of Congolese mines loses citizens $1.3 billion
involvement_in_cases.story:
The Democratic Republic of Congo is fabulously wealthy in natural resources but its people are some of the poorest in the world.

In 2011, just before the Presidential election, the government sold stakes in state-owned mines at significantly below commercial valuations to a series of British Virgin Islands companies. The full list of owners of these companies is secret, but they are associated with a diamond billionaire who is a close friend of the Congolese president. The mines were then sold to major international mining companies for a huge profit.

We do not know who pocketed the difference because company ownership is secret in the British Virgin Islands. But it certainly wasn’t the Congolese people, who have a right to know and who we calculate lost out on at least $1.3 billion from these sales – that’s twice the country’s health and education budget combined.[1]

involvement_in_cases.name: Russian crime boss conned investors out of millions
involvement_in_cases.story:
The FBI has described Semion Mogilevich as “the most dangerous mobster in the world,” allegedly “involved in weapons trafficking, contract murders, extortion, drug trafficking, and prostitution on an international scale.”[1]

According to an indictment, that reputation did not stop the Russian from setting up a vast network of anonymous companies, stretching from Eastern Pennsylvania to the United Kingdom,[2] which allowed him to cheat the stock market and steal over $150 million from investors in the United States and overseas.[3] Many of the investors lost their pensions and retirement savings.[4]

Using his web of anonymous companies, Mogilevich is said to have created the illusion of a successful international business,[5] supposedly trading in industrial magnets. This was complete with glossy annual reports and stock market listings.[6]

The reality was very different. By inflating the price of his companies through manipulating securities and false reporting, including reportedly lying to the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mogilevich convinced investors to purchase millions in stocks in a company that allegedly did no real business. Those involved lost millions.

In spite of several arrest warrants issued against him, Mogilevich still lives freely in Moscow, according to the FBI. He has not been convicted for these crimes.

The case shows how the secrecy that anonymous owners rely on breeds market instability and erodes investor confidence.

involvement_in_cases.name: Ukrainian government overcharged for vaccinations
involvement_in_cases.story:
One of Ukraine’s biggest medical suppliers, Interfarm, ripped off the government by supplying vaccines at double the cost price, according to a court complaint filed in the U.S. Ukraine has very low polio vaccination levels and UNICEF recently warned of a significant risk to the country, stemming from refugees fleeing the war in Syria.[1] For this reason, Ukrainian law prohibits importers from marking up the price of medicines by more than 10%.[2]

According to court documents, Interfarm used an anonymous company from Oregon as a fake middleman to trick the government into purchasing vaccines at around double the cost price.[3] According to the complaint, Interfarm was purchasing vaccines directly from the manufacturer.[4] If this turned out to be true, it would have led to fewer vaccines being purchased, and therefore fewer adults and children being vaccinated. One of the vaccines involved was against polio.[5]

The case was not contested and default judgment was awarded against the Oregon company in 2011. U.S. courts ordered the company to repay $60 million to the Ukrainian state pharmaceutical supplier.[6]

involvement_in_cases.name: NY skyscraper owned by government of Iran
involvement_in_cases.story:
The U.S. government has gone to great lengths to counteract the perceived threat from the Islamic Revolutionary Government of Iran, including making it illegal to provide services to Iran and for entities linked to the state to do business in America.

However, anonymous owners enabled Iran to own a “slice of Manhattan”[1] and profit from its expensive real estate market. A 36- story Manhattan skyscraper on 5th Avenue, which housed the Juicy Couture flagship store, was for many years part-owned by a front for the Iranian government, in direct breach of sanctions. The building was ‘secretly owned and controlled’[2] by the Iranian government using companies incorporated in New York and the UK Crown Dependency of Jersey. In 2013, the U.S. was set to seize control of the building in what the Department of Justice called the largest ever terrorism-related forfeiture. After a lengthy investigation and court case, the judge found that the property’s owners provided services to Iran, which has been against U.S. law since 1995, and that the building was involved in money laundering.[3] The case is due to be appealed.[4]

involvement_in_cases.name: $6 million profits from human trafficking laundered via string of anonymous companies
involvement_in_cases.story:
America has always been a country which welcomes immigrants who want to work for a better life. That promise lay behind a $6 million human trafficking scheme in which anonymous company owners tricked their victims into a life likened to “modern-day slavery.”[1]

Hiding their real identities behind a web of anonymous companies registered in Kansas, Missouri and Ohio,[2] the largely Moldovan gang ran employment companies that sup­plied hundreds of foreign nationals to hotels, resorts and casinos in fourteen states across the U.S.[3]

According to the indictment, victims from Jamaica, the Dominican Republic, the Philippines and elsewhere were lured into the U.S. with false promises and then forced to live in over-priced, overcrowded and sub-standard apartments. The gang withheld much of their earnings, allowed their visas to expire and threatened the workers with deportation and extra fees if they left.[4] They used the anonymous companies to obscure the links between the illegal activity and the main corporation they used in the scam, and to launder their illegal money.[5] The ringleader of the scam was sentenced to twelve years in prison.

involvement_in_cases.name: Mobsters hid behind family trusts
involvement_in_cases.story:

involvement_in_cases.name: Fake AIDS and cancer clinics created to steal more than $70 million from companies and taxpayers
involvement_in_cases.story:
Beginning as early as 2005, anonymous own­ers used an insurance scam to steal approxi­mately $70 million from American businesses and taxpayers. The money was meant to help HIV and cancer sufferers through the govern­ment’s Medicare program.[1]

In one scheme, Michel de Jesus Huarte and associates set up at least 29 “phantom clinics” and submitted false claims for $55 million worth of HIV and cancer treatments to private insurance companies that participated in Medicare Advantage. The sham clinics were paid approximately $14.6 million from American companies even though the clinics did not exist and the treatments were never delivered. [2]

To hide what was going on, the businesses operated behind shell companies registered in Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina and Louisiana. Huarte was able to conceal his ownership of these companies by recruiting nominee owners to sign bank and business documents, and serve as shareholders.[3]

In another fraud scheme, Huarte and other conspirators used phantom clinics in Florida to submit at least $61 million in fake claims directly to Medicare for HIV infusion therapy. Medicare paid the fraudsters at least $23.9 million before they were caught.[4] Huarte pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 22 years in prison in 2010. [5]

involvement_in_cases.name: Churchgoers and military personnel conned out of $82 million
involvement_in_cases.story:
They called themselves the “Three Hebrew Boys”. Touring the southeast United States, Tony Pough, Timothy McQueen and Joseph Brunson targeted religious events to preach about how their faith and an incredible investment opportunity had saved them from crushing debt.[1]

The three criminals tricked churchgoers and military personnel into investing more than $82 million in a Ponzi scheme.[2] Thousands invested their life savings[3] in fake “debt elimination schemes” they were told would wipeout home mortgage payments, student and car loans and credit card debt after a certain period of time.[4]

Victims were required to sign a non-disclosure agreement with a million dollar penalty[5] and then pay into the fraud through the Capital Consortium Group (CCG), an anonymous company from South Carolina controlled by the con men. The crooks characterized CCG as a ministry to make it appear that it was connected to a charitable debt elimination program[6] and claimed that its overseas investments earned 200-500% per night.

In reality very little of the money was invest­ed.[7] Some was used to pay early customers in order to extend the life of the scam, but most of it lined the pockets of the three anonymous company owners, who purchased luxurious goods including high-end automobiles, a private jet and sky box seats at the Carolina Panthers and Atlanta Falcons stadiums.[8] The three are currently serving prison sentences between 27 and 30 years.[9]

involvement_in_cases.name: Armenian organized crime network creates fake healthcare clinics to steal millions from Medicare
involvement_in_cases.story:
Armen Kazarian was the kingpin of an American-Armenian crime syndicate behind the largest ever U.S. Medicare fraud. His scheme stole the identities of doctors and patients to try and rob the government initiative of more than $100 million by submitting fraudulent claims.

Kazarian was a “Vor,” or “thief-in-law,” a select fraternity of senior criminals from the former Soviet Union on which the U.S. authorities have pledged to crack down. He was also an anonymous company owner. involvement_in_cases.name: Anonymous debt collectors preyed on vulnerable homeowners
involvement_in_cases.story:
Imagine being threatened with losing your home, sometimes over a tax bill of a few hundred dollars, and not knowing who you are really up against?

That’s what happened to the victims of Aeon Financial, a company owned anonymously by Mark Alan Schwartz.[1] Targeting thousands of ordinary people including a retired teacher, a hospitalized grocery clerk and a severely disabled woman,[2] Aeon Financial bought up vulnerable Americans’ property tax debts – known as “liens” – in Iowa, Kentucky, Ohio, Maryland and Washington, DC. The company then allegedly piled on legal fees which often increased the debt several times, and gave homeowners a stark choice: pay up or lose your home. This activity is perfectly legal.

The Washington Post uncovered the story in 2013 and tried to peel back the layers of anon­ymous companies to see if they could identify the ultimate owner of Aeon Financial, which was registered in Delaware. It reported that officials in DC didn’t know who the real owners of Aeon were, and that the trail ended with Schwartz.[3] Only after the story received widespread attention, did Schwartz disclose in a letter to the editor in the Washington Post that he is a beneficial owner of the company. Schwartz wrote that “real property tax-lien investors such as Aeon Financial provide an invaluable public service by paying taxes that property owners have failed to pay”.[4]

involvement_in_cases.name: Anonymous companies disguised campaign contributions
involvement_in_cases.story:
Anonymous company ownership has been used to disguise campaign contributions and potential efforts to buy influence over the democratic process in the U.S.

During the 2012 election cycle, NBC reported that a shell company with anonymous owners made a $1 million donation to Restore Our Future, a pro-Mitt Romney PAC. The company was incorporated in Delaware only six weeks before making the donation. It then quickly dissolved, leaving no trace of the person who controlled it two weeks before the PAC made its first campaign filing of the year, which was the first time the public could see its donors.[1]

The negative publicity surrounding this news report led the anonymous company owner to identify himself as Edward Conard (a former Bain Capital executive), which the PAC later confirmed. Conard said that he had made the donation after consulting with law­yers who had reassured him that the donation would comply with election finance laws.[2]

In this instance, public outrage drew the financier into the open - but there is no reason to believe that this is a one-off. As long as people are able to hide the payments they make to political campaigns behind American shell companies with anonymous owners, voters cannot know who is buying what kind of influence over their decision-makers.


[1] NBC News, Firm gives $1 million to pro-Romney group, then dissolves, 4 August 2011, http://www.nbcnews.com/id/44011308/ns/politics-decision_2012/t/firm-gives-million-pro-%20romney-group-then-dissolves/?ns=politics-decision_2012 

[2] NBC News, Mystery million-dollar Romney donor revealed, 6 August 2011, http://www.nbcnews.com/id/44046063/ns/politics/t/mystery-million-dollar-romney-donor-revealed/#.VCWF7fmSySo

involvement_in_cases.name: Palace compound of Ukraine’s former president, Viktor Yanukovych, was secretly owned
involvement_in_cases.story:
Former Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych’s palace compound outside Kiev had a private zoo and chandeliers that cost $100,000 each.[1]  The lavish complex was an emblem of the corruption that fuelled the uprising that led to his downfall in 2014. 

The palace was bought using a complex web of anonymous companies registered in Ukraine, Austria and the U.K. The land on which the building stood was state-owned until 2007, when  it was bought  without any competitive tendering process by a Ukrainian company. That company  sold it to another Ukrainian company which was 99.97% owned by an Austrian company, which in turn was owned by a UK company and an Austrian bank. 

The bank is highly unlikely to be the true owner, but instead will be holding the shares on behalf of someone else whose name remains hidden.  And the UK company is owned by a Liechtenstein trust, which again means that the true ownership remains unknown.[2]

Ukrainian sources told Global Witness that in September 2013, the Austrian company sold the Ukrainian company, and therefore the palace land, to a Ukrainian MP from the same party as Yanukovych called Sergey Klyuyev for 147 million UAH (£8.7m). [3]  Without knowing who is behind the Austrian company, Ukrainians cannot see who benefitted from this sale, but it is not the state. 

[1] Sergeii Leschenko, Yanukovych, the luxury residence and the money trail that leads to London, http://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/serhij-leschenko/yanukovych-luxury-residence-and-money-trail-that-leads-to-london

[2] Global Witness blog, http://www.globalwitness.org/blog/anonymous-uk-company-owned-viktor-yanukovychs-presidential-palace-compound/

involvement_in_cases.name: Switzerland’s oldest bank aided tax evasion
involvement_in_cases.story:
In January 2013, Wegelin, Switzerland’s oldest bank, pleaded guilty to conspiring to help its American clients hide more than a billion dollars from the US tax authorities.

The banks relied on anonymous companies and foundations incorporated in Hong Kong, Panama and Liechtenstein to disguise the ownership of the money. This was the first time that a non-American bank had ever admitted guilt in helping Americans evade tax.

Wegelin has now shut down.[1]

involvement_in_cases.name: The ‘jurisdiction of choice’ for Sarawak’s corrupt
involvement_in_cases.story:
In 2013, a Global Witness sting caught members of the ruling elite in Sarawak, Malaysia explaining how they use secret companies in Singapore and other complex financial arrangements to skirt the country’s laws and sell off huge chunks of land and forest for personal profit.[1]

Posing as an investor wanting to purchase land, cut down the forest and plant palm oil, our investigators were offered ways to evade laws requiring companies to be majority owned by Malaysian nationals by the lawyer to members of the ruling Taib family, Alvin Chong.[2]

Chong promised to keep the profits “locked up offshore” in Singapore, and use Malaysian frontmen as directors and shareholders of the companies involved. When probed as to where such frontmen could be found, Chong said he normally finds villagers from remote communities who will “not be distracted by clever advisers” and who “wouldn’t know how to find a lawyer”.[3]

The film caused outrage in Malaysia when it was released, and triggered a probe by the Malaysian anti-corruption commission.[4]

involvement_in_cases.name: The dead company owner and the Central Asia money laundering scandal
involvement_in_cases.story:
There are few better examples of how extensive the problem of anonymous company ownership is than the case of the dead Russian who owned a company used as a front for what appears to be a billion dollar money-laundering operation.  

Global Witness showed how billions of dollars of suspicious transactions passed through Kyrgyz bank accounts owned by companies registered in UK, New Zealand and Bulgaria.  The money flowed out of the accounts just before a revolution in Kyrgyzstan.  Three of the UK companies had US $1.2 billion running through their accounts despite not being involved in any real business that Global Witness could ascertain.  One of these companies told the UK company registry it was dormant despite having $1.1 million flowing through its accounts. 

The names of the people behind the companies were hidden in various ways.  Some companies had nominee directors, others were owned by companies registered in places such as the British Virgin Islands.  In one case, the identity of a dead man from Russia was used as the front for a UK company.  This person had died three years before the company was set up, yet was listed as the company’s owner and he even ‘attended’ a company meeting in London, according to filings made to the UK company registry.[1] 

[1] Global Witness, Grave Secrecy, http://www.globalwitness.org/library/grave-secrecy

Global Witness showed how billions of dollars of suspicious transactions passed through Kyrgyz bank accounts owned by companies registered in UK, New Zealand and Bulgaria.  The money flowed out of the accounts just before a revolution in Kyrgyzstan.  Three of the UK companies had US $1.2 billion running through their accounts despite not being involved in any real business that Global Witness could ascertain.  One of these companies told the UK company registry it was dormant despite having $1.1 million flowing through its accounts. 

The names of the people behind the companies were hidden in various ways.  Some companies had nominee directors, others were owned by companies registered in places such as the British Virgin Islands.  In one case, the identity of a dead man from Russia was used as the front for a UK company.  This person had died three years before the company was set up, yet was listed as the company’s owner and he even ‘attended’ a company meeting in London, according to filings made to the UK company registry.[1] 

[1] Global Witness, Grave Secrecy, http://www.globalwitness.org/library/grave-secrecy

involvement_in_cases.name: Credit Suisse helped Americans evade tax
involvement_in_cases.story:
For decades, Credit Suisse helped thousands of wealthy Americans evade taxes they should have been paying to the US government.[1]  

For example, the bank helped one US client set up a Hong Kong company and then use that company to open a bank account with Credit Suisse.  The bank even provided their own staff person to act as the nominee director of the Hong Kong company.[2]  Other tricks used included destroying account records and hand-delivering cash so that customers could withdraw money from undeclared accounts.[3]

The US Senate’s Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations estimated that between 85% and 95% of the bank’s Swiss accounts for US clients were hidden from the US authorities and that these accounts held between $5 billion and $13 billion.[4] 

Credit Suisse agreed to pay a $2.5 billion fine in May 2014 in order to settle charges that it helped Americans evade tax.[5]

involvement_in_cases.name: Nicaragua’s former president laundered 8% of annual government spending
involvement_in_cases.story:
Arnoldo Aléman, president of Nicaragua from 1997-2002, and Byron Jerez, a family friend and high ranking official in the Treasury Department, were together convicted of diverting around $100 million of public funds during Aléman’s time in office.[1],[2] This is nearly a tenth of annual government spending in Nicaragua, enough to fund the education budget for a year during a period in which the country’s basic literacy rates were less than half the regional average.[3],[4]

Aléman and Jerez stole the money using a Nicaraguan foundation and anonymous Panamanian companies. They established companies that posed as having legitimate business with the Nicaraguan government, which were used to purchase valuable assets in the U.S., including fixed term bank deposits and a helicopter.[2],[5]

Aleman’s conviction for embezzlement was overturned in 2009. But it is reported that the four justices who voted to absolve Aléman were all linked to his political party and that the decision was heatedly opposed by two other justices.[6],[7] The U.S. government has not returned the assets it seized from him.[8] Jerez was convicted of corruption related criminal offences and sentenced to eight years in jail.[9]

involvement_in_cases.name: Former President of Zambia stole millions of dollars of public money to fund luxury lifestyle
involvement_in_cases.story:
The former President of Zambia, Frederick Chiluba, transferred millions of dollars of public money from the Zambian Ministry of Finance into bank accounts and companies for his own personal use.

One such example is known as the ‘Zamtrop Conspiracy’, named after the London-held bank account that the stolen money was transferred into.[1],[2] By overpaying on fake contracts to two anonymous American companies, Chiluba and his associates conspired to siphon $25 million out of the Zambian Ministry of Finance and into the Zamtrop account.[3]  A British Virgin Islands company with bearer shares was used to buy property in Brussels for one of the co-conspirators.[4] 

The president and other officials were able to steal public money by pretending that the funds were being used for “secret” national security projects.[5]  The money was actually used to fund Chiluba’s expensive wardrobe, cash gifts to family members, jewellery, cars and property.[6]  Chiluba spent $1.2 million – most of which came from the secret Zamtrop account – at a Swiss boutique on handmade shoes and thousands of monogrammed shirts, despite having an annual salary of only about $10,000.[7]  In summing up the case, the judge said that “The people of Zambia should know that whenever [Chiluba] appears in public wearing some of these clothes he acquired them with money stolen from them.”[8]  This happened at a time when most Zambians lived on $1 a day and many could not afford more than one meal a day. [9]

In 2006, Zambia brought a civil case in the UK against those involved in the Zamtrop Conspiracy and another case of fraud, the ‘BK Conspiracy’.  The judge found that all the Zambian defendants, including Chiluba, had conspired to steal millions of dollars of public funds and held them collectively liable for over $25 million.[10]  A criminal case against Chiluba in the Zambian courts resulted in him being acquitted.[11]

involvement_in_cases.name: Millions stolen from the U.S. Navy
involvement_in_cases.story:
Ralph Mariano was an engineer in the U.S. Navy, and had unique access to the government’s procurement process. Between 1999 and 2011, he used this position to funnel $18 million of taxpayers’ money to anonymous companies that he secretly controlled.

Mariano directed navy contractor Advanced Solutions for Tomorrow (ASFT) and its subcontractors to make regular payments to companies that didn’t actually carry out any work for the navy.

Mariano’s friend Russell Spencer submitted false and inflated invoices from his shell companies to ASFT, which in turn submitted them to the navy.[1] After AFST paid Spencer’s companies, Spencer kept some of the money for himself and his family, and then gave the rest to Mariano, Mariano’s father and another shell company[2] that was owned by his lawyer.[3]

In 2013, Mariano pleaded guilty to conspiracy, theft of government funds and tax evasion and was sentenced to ten years in prison and to pay nearly $18 million in restitution. Russell pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit bribery.[4]

[2] United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island, USA vs Ralph Mariano et al, Superseding Indictment, https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/1273831-mariano-superceding-indictment.html#document/p14/a171822

involvement_in_cases.name: Kickbacks demanded for buying coffee
involvement_in_cases.story:
Mark Hoffman was a senior coffee buyer at Sam’s Club in Bentonville, Arkansas. He used an anonymous company set up in the state to demand kickbacks from a California business.

Between 2003 and 2007, Hoffman received $245,800 in kickback payments from Mr. Workman, a coffee vendor at Bay Area Coffee. The deal was simple: as long as Workman paid him, Hoffman promised that Sam’s Club would continue to buy their coffee.[1] Hoffman concealed the payments from Sam’s Club by routing them through Moonlight Support Services LLC, which took cheques from two of Workman’s personal companies.[2] Workman wrote monthly cheques payable to Moonlight Support Services disguised as payments for providing retail analysis reports.[3]

Both men pled guilty and received three years probation and a fine.[4]

involvement_in_cases.name: The former President of Gabon’s $72 million secret company
involvement_in_cases.story:
The former president of Gabon, Omar Bongo, embezzled hundreds of millions of dollars of the country’s oil money.[1] Bongo served as president for 42 years, from 1967 until his death in 2009, in which time he accumulated approximately 66 bank accounts holding over $130 million, 183 cars and 39 luxury properties in France.[2]  The majority of those living in Gabon did not benefit from its huge oil wealth: the country had 900 miles of oil pipeline, but less than 600 miles of paved roads. In contrast, by the time Bongo died, he was one of the richest men in the world.[3]

Bongo held bank accounts in Gabon, London, New York, Paris and Switzerland, the largest of which was under the name of Tendin Investments. [4]  Tendin Investments, a shell corporation registered in the Bahamas, held total funds ranging from about $28 million to $72 million.[5]

Bongo himself was never charged with any wrongdoing during his lifetime. However, in November 2010, the French Supreme Court decided that a criminal complaint filed by several non-governmental organisations against Omar Bongo and his relatives should proceed and be investigated.[6]

involvement_in_cases.name: Americans with bad credit deceived
involvement_in_cases.story:
Credit card scams are increasingly common – almost everyone knows someone who’s been targeted.  Owning an anonymous company offers would-be scammers a particularly easy way to get away with it.

The case of Ira Rubin is a great example.  It shows how Americans with poor credit were tricked into spending hundreds of dollars for a credit card which they never received.

According to the Federal Trade Commission, Rubin set up companies involved in at least nine telemarketing scams targeting Americans.  His lawyer set up[1] at least twenty-four companies, incorporated in places such as the UK, U.S. and Nevis.  

Rubin and his lawyer scammed US customers out of millions of dollars.[2] 

The Federal Trade Commission brought a case in the US courts to try to prevent Rubin from carrying out any more scams, and to compensate victims for their losses.[3]  The case is still ongoing.  In a separate court case Rubin pleaded guilty to laundering money from internet poker games.

involvement_in_cases.name: Zimbabwe government forcibly took diamond mines and handed control to dubious companies
involvement_in_cases.story:
In 2008 the Zimbabwean army took control of the country’s Marange diamond fields using troops and helicopter gunships, killing and wounding many small-scale miners in the process.  Since then, government diamond mining concessions have been allocated to several companies in questionable circumstances.  Mbada Diamonds is one such company.  It is part owned by a company registered in Mauritius, which is itself part owned by a Russian doll-like series of nested Hong Kong and British Virgin Island companies.[1]  Mbada is run by a man widely reported to be Zimbabwean President Mugabe's former helicopter pilot, raising the question as to whether the president may have an interest in the company.[2]

[2] Global Witness, Diamonds: a good deal for Zimbabwe?, February 2012, http://www.globalwitness.org/library/diamonds-good-deal-zimbabwe page 2

involvement_in_cases.name: Former Taiwanese first lady accepted a $6 million bribe to influence her husband
involvement_in_cases.story:
Wu Sue-jen, the wife of former Taiwanese president Chen Shui-bian, accepted a bribe of 200 million New Taiwan Dollars ($6 million) for encouraging her husband to approve a contested company merger.[1]  The money was delivered in ‘five or six fruit boxes’ and was laundered through a series of anonymous companies.[2]  One method involved the use of a New York company, owned by a British Virgins Islands company, to purchase property in Virginia and New York.  The property included a Manhattan apartment worth $1.6 million.[3]   In 2012, a US court seized the ownership of the Manhattan condominium from the BVI company.[4] 

In February 2009, Wu Sue-jen pleaded guilty to money laundering charges in a Taiwanese court.[5]  She was sentenced to jail but has been released due to ill health.[6]  Her husband is serving 17 years in Taiwan on corruption charges.[7]

involvement_in_cases.name: Putin’s associates grossly overcharged Russia for medical supplies
involvement_in_cases.story:
In 2005 President Putin initiated a $1 billion project to build and equip 15 high-tech hospitals.  The project has been beleaguered by corruption.[1]

Reuters alleges that two associates of the president got a share of the $1 billion by using an intermediary company in a $195 million deal to supply medical equipment to the state.  

A company part-owned by the men, Petromed, was paid directly from the public coffers.  The equipment was shipped straight from the supplier to Petromed, but the money went via an anonymous UK company with nominee shareholders and directors, giving the impression that a third party was involved.  This UK company paid the supplier and the equipment was ‘sold on’ to Petromed at mark-ups of up to 100%, according to bank records seen by Reuters.[2]

According to Reuters, the profits from this scheme were laundered through anonymous companies in Belize and Washington DC and at least $48 million went towards a lavish building project on the Black Sea coast, which is popularly known as “Putin’s palace” [3] (though Putin has denied that it is his[4]).

involvement_in_cases.name: Anonymous companies helped launder timber money from the civil war in Sierra Leone
involvement_in_cases.story:
The role of diamonds in funding the civil war in Sierra Leone is well known, thanks to the Hollywood film Blood Diamond and the work of Global Witness.  What’s less well known is that the war was also funded by timber. 

Many of the people who profited from this dirty and destructive trade in timber set up companies in neighbouring countries, particularly Liberia, to launder their money.[1]  

The war in Sierra Leone killed over 50,000 people and contributed to the country’s continuing extreme poverty.[2]  It is among the poorest countries in the world.[3]

involvement_in_cases.name: An anonymous company at the heart of the horsemeat scandal
involvement_in_cases.story:
The horsemeat scandal triggered a food hygiene panic across Europe in 2012. Consumers were shocked to learn that the beef they thought they were buying was in fact horsemeat.  

A Dutchman named Jan Fasen owned a company called Draap, which is Dutch for horse spelled backwards. Draap bought horses slaughtered in Romania, and sold them on to French food processors who in turn supplied companies making frozen meals.[1]

Draap insists that it labelled the meat it sold to France as horse whereas the buyers say it was labelled as beef. Fasen set up the company in Cyprus, but was able to hide his ownership of it behind a trust registered in the British Virgin Islands.[2]

Fasen was charged with fraud in 2014,[3] and convicted in 2012 of passing off South American horsemeat as German and Dutch beef.[4]

involvement_in_cases.name: Nigerian oil minister awarded oil contract to himself and then sold it on for a fortune
involvement_in_cases.story:
Chief Dan Etete was the Nigerian oil minister under the dictatorship of Sani Abacha. Whilst in office he awarded one of the most lucrative oil blocks in Nigeria to Malabu Oil and Gas, a company he secretly owned.[1]

In 2011 subsidiaries of Eni and Royal Dutch Shell agreed to pay US$1.092 billion for this oil block.  The money was paid by Eni and Shell to the Nigerian government, which then paid the same amount to Malabu Oil and Gas. 

This mechanism only came to light when one of the middlemen in the deal sued Malabu in the British High Court for his share of the spoils.  The High Court ruled[2] that Etete was a hidden owner of Malabu and that the Nigerian government had acted as a “straw man” in the deal.

Shell and Eni have denied paying money to Malabu, and it is true that they paid the money to the Nigerian government.  However court evidence has revealed that Shell and Eni knew that the payment was going to Malabu and that Shell had negotiated directly with Etete over “iced champagne”.

The Nigerian House of Representatives voted in February 2014 that the contract with Shell and Eni should be cancelled, and in September 2014 Italian prosecutors raided Eni’s office and announced they were investigating new CEO Claudio Descalzi and other senior executives’ roles in the deal.[3] 

The scandal continues to unfold, but the missing billion has still not benefitted the people of Nigeria.

[1] After General Abacha died in 1998, the administration of Nigerian President Obasanjo revoked Malabu’s licence and awarded it to Royal Dutch Shell, but after much legal wrangling a Nigerian court re-awarded the licence back to Malabu in 2006

[2] UK High Court, Energy Venture Partners vs Malabu Oil & Gas, Commercial court, Queen’s Bench Division, 2011-13, http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Comm/2013/2118.html.  The case was brought by a broker who alleged that Etete failed to pay him for work he had done in obtaining a buyer for OPL245. Shell and Eni were not part of these proceedings

involvement_in_cases.name: Sudan arms embargo allegedly breached
involvement_in_cases.story:
The UN first imposed arms sanctions on Sudan in 2004.[1]  However in 2008 a Ukrainian ship with tanks and other weapons on-board was captured by pirates off the coast of Somalia.  The ship, the MV Faina, was heading for Kenya, and the manifest it was carrying showed that its cargo was destined for ‘GOSS’, widely taken to be the Government of Southern Sudan, which was then part of Sudan and therefore under embargo.[2]  Satellite imagery later appeared to show that the tanks were indeed delivered to Southern Sudan. [3]   Two other ships had also been carrying arms.[4]

According to research carried out by the Small Arms Survey, one of those ships had been chartered by a UK company whose ownership was obscured because it was owned in turn by other companies incorporated in the British Virgin Islands.[5]

involvement_in_cases.story:
The UN first imposed arms sanctions on Sudan in 2004.[1]  However in 2008 a Ukrainian ship with tanks and other weapons on-board was captured by pirates off the coast of Somalia.  The ship, the MV Faina, was heading for Kenya, and the manifest it was carrying showed that its cargo was destined for ‘GOSS’, widely taken to be the Government of Southern Sudan, which was then part of Sudan and therefore under embargo.[2]  Satellite imagery later appeared to show that the tanks were indeed delivered to Southern Sudan. [3]   Two other ships had also been carrying arms.[4]

According to research carried out by the Small Arms Survey, one of those ships had been chartered by a UK company whose ownership was obscured because it was owned in turn by other companies incorporated in the British Virgin Islands.[5]

involvement_in_cases.name: Construction of Trinidad and Tobago airport cost taxpayers $100 million too much
involvement_in_cases.story:
The government of Trinidad and Tobago hired a large firm, Birk Hillman Consultants Inc, to manage the construction of what’s now the country’s busiest airport.[1],[2]

A contract for providing x-ray scanners and other equipment was awarded to Calmaquip, a Florida company controlled by Raul Gutierrez.[3],[4]  This contract came in at $15 million more than had been estimated by an independent surveyor. [5]  The only other company to submit a bid was an international firm with a Florida subsidiary that shared corporate officers, directors and a business location with Calmaquip, suggesting they had the same people behind them.  Neither Calmaquip nor the other firm disclosed their relationship with each other,[6] but they colluded to ensure that Calmaquip’s overpriced bid was the smaller of the two.[7]  Had Trinidad and Tobago required companies submitting bids to reveal their ultimate beneficial owners, their relationship would have been clear and Trinidad would presumably have been less likely to have accepted an overpriced bid.

The proceeds of the scheme were funnelled through anonymous companies incorporated in the Bahamas and Panama and eventually made their way into real estate, shares of stock and 27 different bank accounts in Florida.[8], [9]

The government estimated that the scheme defrauded the Trinidadian people of $105 million,[10] a sum equivalent to 10% of the country’s education budget.[11]

Raul Gutierrez was sent to jail for 6 years for his role in this scheme.[12]

involvement_in_cases.name: Kenyan taxpayers robbed of $1 billion in ‘Anglo-Leasing’ scandal
involvement_in_cases.story:
In 2004, a former presidential anti-corruption advisor, John Githongo, blew the whistle on a massive Kenyan corruption scandal.  The scandal has become known as the ‘Anglo Leasing’ affair, after the name of one of the anonymous companies involved.  It has been written about extensively in the press[1] and covered in-depth in a book by Michaela Wrong.[2]

According to the World Bank,[3] over 20 government contracts were awarded in Kenya at inflated prices during the presidencies of Daniel Arap Moi and Mwai Kibaki.  Several different companies were used as fronts in the fraud.[4]  

Many of the contracts related to security issues, such as passport controls, security vehicles and police supplies.[5]  By pretending that the contracts were for urgent national security needs, the usual processes for awarding contracts were avoided.  For instance, a contract for the supply of passport and visa issuing systems, which should have cost around €6 million, was instead awarded to the anonymous company Anglo Leasing Finance, for €32 million[6].  The Kenya Anticorruption Commission stated that Anglo Leasing was a British company[7]; it turns out that it has an address in Liverpool but is incorporated in the British Virgin Islands, with hidden ownership.[8] 

In all, the over-priced contracts cost the Kenyan government nearly $1 billion[9], in a country where over 40% of the population live on less than $1.25 a day[10].  The case as a whole has never gone to trial in Kenya, however a Kenyan government audit report states that several of the companies involved made voluntary refunds during the investigations, with Anglo Leasing Finance returning $4.7 million.[11]  None of the officials involved has been brought to justice.

involvement_in_cases.name: Hewlett-Packard Russia funnelled bribes to Russian officials
involvement_in_cases.story:
Hewlett-Packard Russia, a wholly owned subsidiary of Hewlett Packard,[1] set up a “cascading series of shell companies”[2] to hide the bribes it was making to Russian officials to secure lucrative telecommunications and computing infrastructure contracts.[3] 

The company funnelled bribes of $2.8 million through a UK anonymous company called Burwell Consulting,[4] while others were transferred through U.S., British Virgin Island and Belize companies.[5] 

According to the U.S. authorities, Hewlett-Packard Russia “created a slush fund for bribe payments [and] set up an intricate web of shell companies and bank accounts to launder money.”[6] The bribed officials spent the money on expensive jewellery and luxury cars, among other things.[7] 

Hewlett Packard Russia pleaded guilty in 2014 and agreed to pay a $58.8 million fine to the US authorities to resolve these charges.[8]

involvement_in_cases.name: The UK arms company scandal
involvement_in_cases.story:
The British arms firm BAE Systems admitted making false statements about payments made around the world to help win arms contracts. Investigators from The Guardian say that UK police estimated that as much as £6bn may have been paid in corrupt commissions.[1]  BAE made payments to ‘marketing advisors’ through offshore shell companies and encouraged these advisors to establish their own offshore companies to make and receive payments. involvement_in_cases.story:
The role of diamonds in funding the civil war in Sierra Leone is well known, thanks to the Hollywood film Blood Diamond and the work of Global Witness.  What’s less well known is that the war was also funded by timber. 

Many of the people who profited from this dirty and destructive trade in timber set up companies in neighbouring countries, particularly Liberia, to launder their money.[1]  

The war in Sierra Leone killed over 50,000 people and contributed to the country’s continuing extreme poverty.[2]  It is among the poorest countries in the world.[3]

involvement_in_cases.name: Haitian government official laundered half a million dollars of bribes
involvement_in_cases.story:
Haiti is one of the poorest countries in the world and it has consistently ranked as one of the most corrupt.[1]

Between 2003 and 2006, Jean Rene Duperval, a former director of international relations at Haiti Teleco, was paid almost half a million dollars in bribes.[2]

Terra Telecommunications Corp.,[3] a Miami-based telecoms company, and Cinergy Telecommunications Inc. paid Duperval $497,331 in kickbacks in exchange for preferential calling rates, a continued telecommunications connection and to ensure a renewal of their contracts with Haiti Teleco, the sole provider of landline telephone services in Haiti.[4]  Cinergy was later found to be a paper company – non-operational with no employees and no assets of any real value.[5]

To conceal the bribe payments, Duperval used “a cloak of shell corporations and fake invoices”,[6] including a Florida-based anonymous company called Telecom Consulting.[7]  He instructed Terra and Cinergy to forward the payments to Telecom Consulting, owned by his sister,[8] Marguerite Grandison.[9] The payments were backed up by false documents identifying them as fees for “international minutes from the USA to Haiti” or “consulting services”. The services were never provided.[10] Telecom Consulting then transferred the funds to Duperval, disguised as “commissions” or “payroll” payments.[11]

In May 2012, Duperval was convicted on two counts of conspiracy to commit money laundering and nineteen counts of money laundering, in violation of the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, Haitian bribery law and the wire fraud statute.[12] He was fined $497,331[13] and sentenced to nine years imprisonment.[14]  An appeal process is underway.[15]

involvement_in_cases.name: Nicaragua’s former president laundered 8% of annual government spending
involvement_in_cases.story:
Arnoldo Aléman, president of Nicaragua from 1997-2002, and Byron Jerez, a family friend and high ranking official in the Treasury Department, were together convicted of diverting around $100 million of public funds during Aléman’s time in office.[1],[2] This is nearly a tenth of annual government spending in Nicaragua, enough to fund the education budget for a year during a period in which the country’s basic literacy rates were less than half the regional average.[3],[4]

Aléman and Jerez stole the money using a Nicaraguan foundation and anonymous Panamanian companies. They established companies that posed as having legitimate business with the Nicaraguan government, which were used to purchase valuable assets in the U.S., including fixed term bank deposits and a helicopter.[2],[5]

Aleman’s conviction for embezzlement was overturned in 2009. But it is reported that the four justices who voted to absolve Aléman were all linked to his political party and that the decision was heatedly opposed by two other justices.[6],[7] The U.S. government has not returned the assets it seized from him.[8] Jerez was convicted of corruption related criminal offences and sentenced to eight years in jail.[9]

involvement_in_cases.name: Former President of Nigeria faked national emergencies to steal $2 billion from his country
involvement_in_cases.story:
When General Sani Abacha was the President of Nigeria in the 1990s he asked security advisors to send him written requests for millions of U.S. dollars, British pounds sterling, and Nigerian naira for unidentified national "emergencies"[1].  More than 60 such false national security letters were submitted[2], each resulting in public funds being withdrawn from the state bank.[3] In total, more than $2 billion was stolen. [4]

Instead of being used for national security purposes[5] the funds were moved out of Nigeria and deposited into accounts controlled by General Abacha or other members of the conspiracy.[6]  Companies registered in the British Virgin Islands and bank accounts and assets held in the United Kingdom, France and Jersey were all used to hold the funds.[7]

The numbers of people living in poverty in Nigeria increased during Sani Abacha’s rule.[8]  $2 billion would go a long way to helping alleviate such problems. 

The US authorities successfully brought a case that resulted in more than $458 million, in bank accounts belonging to the companies named here, and other bank accounts, being frozen.  This civil asset recovery case was not contested by General Abacha or anyone else.[9] [10]

In the 1990s, the Nigerian government defaulted on its debt to a Russian company TPE.[1]  The debt was then bought by Abubakar Bagudu, a friend of the then President of Nigeria’s son Mohammed Abacha via an anonymously owned BVI company[2] that was controlled by Bagudu and the president’s son.[3]

U.S. prosecutors brought a case in the US courts to try to recover more than $500 million that they alleged had been embezzled by General Abacha, his son and others.[4]  The prosecutors alleged that Bagudu was assured by the Nigerian government that were the BVI company to buy the debt, the government would then buy it from them at an inflated price.[5] Indeed, the government did then go on to buy its own debt back for twice the market price,[6] defrauding the Nigerian people out of more than $282 million.[7]  According to the U.S. prosecutors, the money ended up in the pockets of Mohammed Abacha and Abubakar Bagudu.[8]

The U.S. court complaint further alleges that Nigeria's purchase of the debt was personally approved by President General Abacha, even though the country would have saved hundreds of millions of dollars by buying the debt at the original price on the open market.[9]

The case was not contested and a default judgment was awarded, meaning that the money in the various bank accounts identified in the court case was seized by the US authorities.[10]

involvement_in_cases.name: Former President of Nigeria faked national emergencies to steal $2 billion from his country
involvement_in_cases.story:
When General Sani Abacha was the President of Nigeria in the 1990s he asked security advisors to send him written requests for millions of U.S. dollars, British pounds sterling, and Nigerian naira for unidentified national "emergencies"[1].  More than 60 such false national security letters were submitted[2], each resulting in public funds being withdrawn from the state bank.[3] In total, more than $2 billion was stolen. [4]

Instead of being used for national security purposes[5] the funds were moved out of Nigeria and deposited into accounts controlled by General Abacha or other members of the conspiracy.[6]  Companies registered in the British Virgin Islands and bank accounts and assets held in the United Kingdom, France and Jersey were all used to hold the funds.[7]

The numbers of people living in poverty in Nigeria increased during Sani Abacha’s rule.[8]  $2 billion would go a long way to helping alleviate such problems. 

The US authorities successfully brought a case that resulted in more than $458 million, in bank accounts belonging to the companies named here, and other bank accounts, being frozen.  This civil asset recovery case was not contested by General Abacha or anyone else.[9] [10]

involvement_in_cases.name: Notorious DC-lobbyist Jack Abramoff defrauded clients out of millions of dollars
involvement_in_cases.story:
Jack Abramoff was a Washington DC-based lobbyist who was involved in a big Congressional corruption scandal.  The 2010 Hollywood film, Casino Jack, follows this story and stars Kevin Spacey as Jack Abramoff. [1] 

In 2006 Abramoff pleaded guilty to defrauding his lobbying clients out of millions of dollars and bribing public officials.  He was ordered to pay more than $23 million back to his victims, mainly to Native American tribes.[2]  Native Americans are the poorest major ethnic group in the US, with more than a quarter of people living below the poverty line.[3]  The inflated prices charged generated huge profits, half of which went back to Abramoff himself.[4]

Money from Abramoff’s clients was used to bribe public officials, usually Congressmen and their staffers, in return for influence.[5]  The bribes including things such as an all-expenses paid trip to a Pacific island and a golfing trip to Scotland. [6] 

The money was funnelled through several companies established by Abramoff and his associates.[7]  One of these was the American International Center (AIC), a Delaware corporation which claimed to be a think tank, but was instead a sham company used to collect and divert funds.[8]  It was used in three ways:[9]

To receive payments from foreign governments, as a way of getting round the legal requirement for foreign governments lobbying in the US to have to register.

To disguise the fact that Abramoff was lobbying on behalf of Native American tribes.  Abramoff did not want to be publicly associated with them.  $4 million was moved in this way.

To funnel kickbacks from Native American tribes to one of Abramoff’s co-conspirators, who used the money for personal expenses. 

AIC’s directors were two friends of Abramoff: a lifeguard and a yoga instructor.[10] 

Abramoff was sentenced to four years in jail in 2008.[11]  Twenty-one other people have also pleaded guilty or been found guilty in relation to this case, including White House officials, a Congressman and Congressional aides.[12]

involvement_in_cases.name: Anonymous company used to buy Manhattan apartment by person convicted of insider trading
involvement_in_cases.story:
Hong Kong businesswoman Sun Min used a British Virgin Islands company, Jolly Star Holding Ltd., to purchase a $15 million apartment near Central Park in Manhattan. [1]  The company’s ownership of this apartment would have remained anonymous had it not been for confidential records obtained by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists.[2]

A few months prior to the purchase of the Manhattan condominium, Sun Min and her husband bought more than 8 million shares in Huiyuan, a Chinese juice company.  The purchase was made after illegal information had been obtained by Min about Coca-Cola’s interest in purchasing Huiyuan. [3]  Between the shares purchase and the public announcement of Coca-Cola’s interest, the juice-maker’s stock value soared and Min began to sell-off the shares, reaping millions in profits, according to the ICIJ.[4]  In 2013, a Hong Kong tribunal found Min guilty of insider trading[5], fining her more than $3 million. [6]
