involvement_in_cases.name: Footballer Lionel Messi’s alleged tax evasion scheme
involvement_in_cases.story:
Lionel Messi is a footballer who plays for FC Barcelona and the Argentinian national team and is widely regarded as one of the best players in the world.  He has been accused in the Spanish courts of tax evasion.  The case has yet to be heard; what follows are the allegations made by the Spanish prosecutor. 

According to the prosecutor, Lionel Messi’s alleged multi-million euro tax evasion scheme[i] relied upon hiding the names of the real owners of companies registered in the UK, Switzerland, Uruguay and Belize.

It has been widely reported that the prosecution alleges the scheme involved funnelling money to tax havens using a complex web of shell companies.[ii]  What’s not so well known is their allegation that the scheme also relied on keeping the names of the true owners of the companies involved hidden from the public.  The Spanish prosecutor states that the money was routed through UK and Swiss companies and then on to companies in the tax havens of Uruguay and Belize; he also claims that all these countries were used because they allow opaque corporate structures. [iii]  Messi denies the allegations against him, saying that the deals were done by his former agent without his knowledge.[iv] 

The ownership of the companies allegedly used in this scheme was hidden by the use of:

  • Nominees (used to hide the ownership of the Swiss company Lazario GmbH and the UK company Sidefloor Ltd).  Nominees are people or companies who are listed in official documents as the owners or directors of a company, but who in fact merely own or control the company on behalf of someone else through hidden arrangements. 
  • Having shareholders that are companies that are registered somewhere that keeps ownership details secret (used to hide the ownership of the UK company Sport Enterprises Ltd, which was 50% owned by a Uruguayan company).  Not only does Uruguay does not make any information about the owners or directors of its companies public, it does not even require all companies to keep any information as to who they are owned by.

[i] Lionel Messi and his father are accused of evading 4.2 million euros in tax on earnings from sponsors.  The detail of what he’s been accused of, as well as information on the companies named here can be found in the formal complaint filed by the prosecutor Raquel Amado, Al juzgado de instrucción en funciones de Guardia de Gavá, http://www.as.com/misc/pdf/Messi-Querella.pdf

[ii] For example, see The Guardian (http://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/sep/27/lionel-messi-tax-fraud-court-barcelona,. The Daily Mail (http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2346352/Messis-guilty-claim-legal-team--WILL-cough-3-4m-tax-fine.html), the BBC (http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-24292849).  

[iii] Before 2006, the money was routed through:

  • a UK company called Sport Enterprises Ltd which was set up by the UK branch of a Gibraltar company service provider called Sovereign.  The ownership of the company was obscured: half of the shares were owned by a Uruguayan company called Goodshire SA. 
  • a Swiss company called Lazario GmbH.  The ownership of the company was obscured: it is owned by another Swiss company, whose declared activities consist of performing fiduciary duties; in other words, it is owned by a nominee.  

After 2006, money was routed through “equally opaque” companies:

  • a UK company called Sidefloor Ltd.  Sidefloor has a sole owner and director: Mr Ayomide Otubanjo.  The Spanish prosecutor states that the ownership of this company “corresponds” to Bedford Nominees (UK) Ltd, which is owned by Jordans Trust Company Ltd which is owned by West of England Trust Ltd.  All of these are nominee service providers. 
  • a Swiss company called Tubal Soccer Management GmbH
  • a Uruguay company called Jenbril SA

Alleged in the formal complaint filed by the prosecutor Raquel Amado, Al juzgado de instrucción en funciones de Guardia de Gavá, http://www.as.com/misc/pdf/Messi-Querella.pdf.

[iv] The Guardian, http://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/sep/27/lionel-messi-tax-fraud-court-barcelona

involvement_in_cases.name: Ariel Sharon’s son used an anonymous company to funnel illegal campaign funds
involvement_in_cases.story:
Omri Sharon, the son of the former Prime Minister of Israel Ariel Sharon, was convicted in 2006 of receiving illegal contributions for his father’s successful election campaign to become leader of the Likud Party in 1999.[1] 

Omri Sharon, who was himself also an elected politician, received more than $1.3m in campaign funds from Israeli and overseas corporations between July 1999 and February 2000, significantly more than is allowed by Israeli law.[2]  He established an anonymous Israeli company called Annex Research Ltd which was used to receive and hold the funds.[3]

Omri Sharon was convicted of violating Israel’s political party funding law and was sentenced to jail.[4]

involvement_in_cases.story:
The ex-President of Chile, Augusto Pinochet, is well-known for human rights abuses, torture and assassinations.  He was also engaged in grand-scale corruption.[1]  The Chilean Supreme Court estimated that Pinochet had a secret fortune of more than $20 million, of which less than 10% could be accounted for by his official military salary.[2] 

Pinochet used two anonymous shell companies in the Bahamas, Ashburton Company and Althorp Investment, to hold money offshore.[3]  The anonymous companies and their bank accounts were set up by Riggs bank in Washington DC. [4]  The US Senate’s Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations found that Riggs set up these companies in order “to disguise Mr Pinochet’s ownership of the account funds” [5] and concluded that the bank had “assisted Augusto Pinochet […] to evade legal proceedings […] despite red flags involving the source of Mr. Pinochet’s wealth, pending legal proceedings to freeze his assets, and public allegations of serious wrongdoing”.[6]
